title.narrative: Human rights protection through increasing monitoring, reporting, legal advice, capacity building and advocacy on International Humanitarian Law (IHL) and International Human Rights Law (IHRL) in the United Nations Syria response

description.narrative:
This project is part of an overall programme through which the OHCHR Syria Office strengthens its support to the humanitarian leadership and partners in implementing a robust response based on expanded factual data and legal analysis for the protection of human rights. The Office’s work is done remotely from Beirut, Lebanon as the Syrian Government does not allow OHCHR access to the country. OHCHR delivers a complementary range of programming elements – monitoring/reporting, legal analysis, and technical cooperation – which backstop the Human Rights Advisors who work with the Resident Coordinator/Humanitarian Coordinator (RC/HC) and the humanitarian leadership in Syria as well as the Regional Humanitarian Coordinator (RHC) and Deputy Regional Humanitarian Coordinator (DRHC). This innovative model allows the Office to provide a whole package of support and advisory services including regular data/analysis and legal review as well as responding to humanitarians’ ad hoc requests based on developments on the ground.
Supporting protection activities aiming to prevent, stop, or remedy violations of rights in life-threatening contexts, such as the provision of protection-related and life-saving information to affected people is the central element of this OHCHR Syria project submission. Its key objective is to expand human rights monitoring, analysis, reporting, advice, advocacy and other engagements, including through the referrals of victims/survivors to service providers with a special focus on the rights of groups most at risk of being discriminated against, including women, girls, young people, adolescents, and persons with disabilities.
Using its monitoring, documentation and legal analysis of the human rights situation and patterns of violations by parties on the ground to support UN protection and advocacy, OHCHR’s concrete activities will support prevention and mitigate protection risks for the most vulnerable in Syria. This Protection-HR project directly targets approximately 500 affected people, however its value resides in the support function provided to the humanitarian coordination architecture and the protection analysis for the WoS, through advocacy, legal notes, humanitarian due diligence and human rights monitoring, to name a few.
